[[File:Chernobyl Disaster.jpg|thumb|200px|upright|[[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl reactor 4]] exploded sending a radioactive cloud across [[Europe]].]]
  â  
The '''International Nuclear and Radiological Event Scale''' ('''INES''') was introduced in 1990<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Event_scale_revised_for_further_clarity_0510081.html |title=Event scale revised for further clarity |publisher=World-nuclear-news.org |date=6 October 2008 |accessdate=13 September 2010}}</ref> by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) in order to enable prompt communication of [[nuclear safety|safety]] significance information in case of [[nuclear accident]]s.
The '''International Nuclear and Radiological Event Scale''' ('''INES''') was introduced in 1990<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS_Event_scale_revised_for_further_clarity_0510081.html |title=Event scale revised for further clarity |publisher=World-nuclear-news.org |date=6 October 2008 |accessdate=13 September 2010}}</ref> by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) in order to enable prompt communication of [[nuclear safety|safety]] significance information in case of [[nuclear accident]]s.
